ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
We often did not have class so that we could work independently.

Mostly, a virtual studio, with each student and instructors camera on into their own workspace. Occasionally a hybrid model of socially-distanced outdoor in-person gathering of the few new haven-based students for location-based landscape work with others zooming in

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to use lines to create drawings, learned different techniques with charcoal and midtone papers, how to draw from observation
Basic techniques/concepts of drawing, including shading/contour/crosshatching, etc.
I learned how to draw using charcoal, how to draw from observation, to get my creativity flowing, and practice mark-making.
How to use drawing materials, techniques to be able to accurately draw from life, techniques to capture light and perspective, how to create a conceptual drawing, how to draw a self portrait.

I learned how to develop more ease, confidence, and precision making marks with different media (eg different graphites and charcoals) and how to stage or observe and then develop compositions. I feel much better prepared to interpret my visual world spatially and less intimidated by making art after taking this course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: fun class, learn a lot about how to observe and draw; weaknesses: wish we could've been more creative with what we got to draw

At times the course felt disorganized (final presentations were during finals week instead of reading period) but given the online learning situation, it was handled pretty well. Students had freedom to work on projects while being in close contact with the instructor.
It is a great course for people who have never drawn before and for those who have some experience as well. The major strength is the professor isn't looking for perfection, but rather for effort.
Strengths were that we were given a lot of independent time to work and freedom on the final. Weaknesses were that often times this freedom did not work for everyone in the course equally.

I loved this course, and I really appreciated Christians care for his students and thoughtfulness to adapt to the pandemic conditions! Strengths definitely include his emphasis on problem solving (and on that note, I really loved the outdoor excursions to the cemetery), class time to share and critique our progress, the uplifting quality of Christians simple enthusiasm and constructive support (he also provided helpful guidance on how students can constructively critique each others work)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Giving class time to work on art was a great way to engage.
The virtual format succeeded.
Strengths were that we were given a lot of independent time to work. We also  Weaknesses were that often times this freedom did not work for everyone in the course equally.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the course was really fun overall and was a good creative outlet compared to other distributional requirements. It will definitely help you develop your skills in observation and different techniques
Yes! It is a fun class to draw and think about drawing, even if you know a lot.
Yes! I took this course because I took art in high school and I missed taking art classes at Yale. It's great to refine your existing drawing and observational skills.
Yes, if you want to improve your drawing skills.
Yes! Take it with Christian if you can for strong foundational skills with a supportive prof.
